<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mutex:
```c
static int mutex(void)
{
	metal_mutex_t lock;
	const int threads = 10;
	int rc;

	metal_mutex_init(&lock);

	rc = metal_run(threads, mutex_thread, &lock);

	metal_mutex_deinit(&lock);

	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function mutex:
typedef struct {
	atomic_int v;
} metal_mutex_t
...
int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
...
static void *mutex_thread(void *arg)
{
	metal_mutex_t *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < mutex_test_count; i++) {
		metal_mutex_acquire(l);
		usleep(1);
		metal_mutex_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
...
int metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child,
		     void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out)
{
	int error, i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	error = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++) {
		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to create thread - %s\n",
				  strerror(error));
			break;
		}
	}

	*threads_out = i;
	return error;
}
...
void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragments. Specific notes:

- pthread_t tids[threads]; is a variable length array (VLA). VLAs are a standard C99 feature (optional in C11) and are a language feature, not a compiler-specific extension. The rule requires reporting only when a construct is explicitly documented as a compiler extension; this usage is not necessarily such an extension.

- Use of pthreads (pthread_create, pthread_join, pthread_t) are POSIX library APIs, not compiler language extensions. They are platform/library interfaces, so they do not fall under MISRA Rule 1.2 about compiler language extensions.

- atomic_int used inside metal_mutex_t is a standard C11 atomic type (from <stdatomic.h>), not a compiler extension.

- Pointer casts (e.g., (pthread_t *)tids, (void *)tids) and returning void* from the thread function are standard C and standard pthread usage, not compiler extensions.

- No occurrences of known compiler-specific extensions (for example: __attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), inline asm, MSVC-specific keywords, or other vendor-specific language extensions) are present in the shown code.

Therefore there are no code fragments that explicitly use compiler language extensions that must be reported for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
